snippet: It took jurors only three hours to convict Vilma Bautista on conspiracy and tax fraud charges stemming from the sale or attempted sale of the paintings, which disappeared in the 1980s.
abstract: Vilma Bautista, longtime confidante of Imelda Marcos and her personal secretary, is convicted in Manhattan of conspiracy and tax fraud; charges stem from attempted sale of Impressionist masterpieces that once hung on walls of townhouse used by Imelda Marcos; millions of dollars’ worth of artwork purchased with public money went missing from Philippines after Ferdinand Marcos was ousted as president in 1980s.
lead_paragraph: It took jurors only three hours to convict Vilma Bautista on conspiracy and tax fraud charges stemming from the sale or attempted sale of the paintings, which disappeared in the 1980s.

headline.main: Former Marcos Aide Is Convicted in Attempted Sale of Missing Paintings
headline.print_headline: Former Marcos Aide Is Convicted in Attempted Sale of Missing Paintings
